title: Tags and Organization in Hiver
content:
Tags are powerful tools for organizing, categorizing, and tracking emails in Hiver.

Creating and Managing Tags:

1. Create a Tag:
   - Click the tag icon in an email
   - Select 'Create New Tag'
   - Choose a name and color
   - Set visibility (personal or shared)

2. Tag Types:
   - Shared Tags: Visible to entire team
   - Personal Tags: Only you can see
   - System Tags: Auto-generated by Hiver

3. Applying Tags:
   - Manual: Click tag icon and select
   - Automatic: Via automations
   - Bulk: Select multiple emails and tag at once

Tag Organization Strategies:

1. By Category:
   - Product inquiries
   - Billing questions
   - Technical support
   - Feature requests
   - Complaints

2. By Priority:
   - Urgent
   - High priority
   - Normal
   - Low priority

3. By Status:
   - Needs review
   - Waiting on customer
   - Escalated
   - Follow-up required

4. By Customer Type:
   - VIP customers
   - Enterprise clients
   - Free tier users
   - Trial users

Using Tags Effectively:

1. Filtering and Search:
   - Click a tag to see all tagged emails
   - Combine multiple tags for precise filtering
   - Save filtered views for quick access

2. Analytics:
   - Track volume by tag
   - Measure response times per category
   - Identify trending issues

3. Automations:
   - Auto-tag based on keywords
   - Auto-assign based on tags
   - Trigger workflows with tag changes

4. Reporting:
   - Generate reports by tag
   - Track tag usage over time
   - Export tagged conversations

Best Practices:

- Keep tag names clear and concise
- Use consistent naming conventions
- Limit the number of tags (avoid tag bloat)
- Use colors meaningfully (e.g., red for urgent)
- Document tag meanings for team alignment
- Regularly audit and clean up unused tags
- Combine tags with other features (assignments, status)

Common Tag Hierarchies:
- Department > Category > Subcategory
- Priority > Type > Status
- Customer Tier > Issue Type > Resolution Stage

Advanced Features:
- Tag dependencies and rules
- Conditional tag application
- Tag-based SLA tracking
- Tag analytics and insights

Tips:
- Start simple, add complexity as needed
- Train team on tag usage
- Review tag effectiveness monthly
- Use automations to ensure consistent tagging
